title: Status Migrainosus
scope: ** Evaluation and management of status migrainosus (debilitating migraine lasting >72 hours), including acute abortive therapy, rescue protocols, and prevention of recurrence. Excludes routine migraine management, chronic migraine prophylaxis initiation, cluster headache, and secondary headache disorders.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Rule out infection, anemia contributing to headache
Electrolyte abnormalities from dehydration/vomiting; renal function for medication dosing
Hypomagnesemia lowers migraine threshold and is common in status migrainosus

Essential/Core Labs.item: Pregnancy test (hCG, women of childbearing age) (CPT 84703)
Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Pregnancy status affects treatment selection (contraindication to triptans, DHE, valproate)
Thyroid dysfunction as contributing factor to refractory headache

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Rule out giant cell arteritis (age >50, new-onset) or inflammatory etiology
Deficiency associated with increased migraine frequency and chronification
Iron deficiency associated with migraine; may contribute to refractoriness
Baseline before valproate or repeated NSAID use
Baseline before valproate; elevated levels worsen encephalopathy
Assess for metabolic derangement in prolonged vomiting/dehydration

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Occult substance use contributing to headache; medication overuse
If fever present or meningitis suspected
Suspected vasculitis or autoimmune etiology in atypical presentation
Elevated levels associated with migraine with aura; refractory cases

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rule out elevated ICP (IIH) or low-pressure headache
SAH if CT negative and >12 hours from onset

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate if thunderclap onset, new focal deficit, altered mental status, worst headache of life
Before DHE, triptan, or antiemetic administration
Essential/First-line.target: Normal QTc (<470 ms women, <450 ms men), no ischemia

Extended.timing: When stable; new headache pattern, refractory to treatment, atypical features
Extended.target: Normal; rule out structural lesion, pituitary apoplexy, Chiari malformation

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: If mass, infection, inflammation, or venous thrombosis suspected
If cerebral venous thrombosis suspected (postpartum, OCP use, papilledema)
All patients; assess for papilledema suggesting elevated ICP

Rare/Specialized.timing: If cervical artery dissection suspected (neck pain, Horner syndrome)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for diagnosis confirmation, treatment escalation guidance, and preventive strategy
Headache specialist referral for chronic migraine management and refractory status migrainosus
Pain management consult for refractory cases not responding to standard protocols, nerve block consideration
Ophthalmology consult if papilledema found on fundoscopic exam to rule out IIH
Psychiatry or behavioral health referral for comorbid anxiety, depression, or significant psychosocial stressors contributing to refractoriness
Social work consult for discharge planning, outpatient resource coordination, and insurance authorization for specialty medications
Physical therapy referral for cervicogenic component evaluation, trigger point therapy, and postural correction
Infusion center referral for outpatient DHE or ketamine infusion protocol if refractory

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Return immediately if thunderclap headache onset, fever, neck stiffness, new neurologic deficits, or altered mental status develop (may indicate secondary cause requiring emergency evaluation)
Return to ED if headache recurs at severe intensity within 72 hours of discharge despite rescue medications (may require repeat parenteral therapy)
Treat recurrent migraine within the first hour of onset for maximal medication efficacy (early treatment is more effective than delayed treatment)
Avoid medication overuse: limit triptans to no more than 9 days per month and NSAIDs to no more than 14 days per month to prevent medication overuse headache
Keep a detailed headache diary documenting frequency, severity (0-10), triggers, medications used, and response to treatment for follow-up appointments
Follow up with neurology or headache specialist within 2-4 weeks of discharge for preventive therapy initiation and treatment plan adjustment
Do not drive until headache has fully resolved and no sedating medications are on board due to impaired reaction time and concentration
Take all prescribed discharge medications as directed and do not abruptly discontinue steroids if prescribed a taper (may cause rebound headache or adrenal insufficiency)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Maintain a regular sleep schedule of 7-8 hours per night as both sleep deprivation and oversleeping are established migraine triggers
Regular aerobic exercise (30 minutes, 5 days per week) reduces migraine frequency through endorphin release and stress reduction
Stress management with biofeedback, progressive muscle relaxation, or cognitive behavioral therapy (Level A evidence for migraine prevention)
Stay well-hydrated with at least 64 ounces of water daily as dehydration is a common and modifiable migraine trigger
Avoid known dietary triggers including alcohol (especially red wine), aged cheeses, MSG, processed meats, and skipped meals
Limit caffeine to consistent moderate intake (less than 200 mg per day) and avoid abrupt caffeine withdrawal which is a potent headache trigger
Discuss preventive medication initiation at follow-up if experiencing 4 or more migraine days per month, significant disability, or recurrent status migrainosus episodes
Identify and manage comorbid conditions that worsen migraine including depression, anxiety, insomnia, and obesity

differential.features: Thunderclap onset ("worst headache of life"), neck stiffness, rapid deterioration, no prior migraine history
differential.tests: CT head (sensitivity >95% within 6h); LP if CT negative (xanthochromia)

differential.features: Progressive headache, seizures, focal deficits, risk factors (OCP, pregnancy, prothrombotic state), papilledema
differential.tests: MRV or CT venogram; D-dimer (low sensitivity)

differential.features: Papilledema, visual obscurations, pulsatile tinnitus, bilateral pressure headache worse with Valsalva; often obese women
differential.tests: Fundoscopic exam, LP with elevated opening pressure (>25 cm H2O), MRI with empty sella/optic nerve sheath distension

differential.features: Acute neck pain, Horner syndrome (miosis, ptosis), preceding trauma or neck manipulation, focal neurologic deficits
differential.tests: CTA head/neck or MRA with fat-suppressed sequences

differential.features: Age >50, new-onset headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, visual symptoms, constitutional symptoms
differential.tests: ESR/CRP markedly elevated; temporal artery biopsy; temporal artery ultrasound (halo sign)

differential.features: Chronic daily headache (≥15 days/month), frequent acute medication use (>10-15 days/month for >3 months), headache worsens with continued overuse
differential.tests: Detailed medication diary; headache improves within 2 months of medication withdrawal

differential.features: Fever, neck stiffness, photophobia, altered mental status, rash (meningococcal); may present subacutely
differential.tests: LP (cell count, protein, glucose, culture, PCR); blood cultures

differential.features: Progressive headache worse in morning or with Valsalva, new focal deficits, papilledema, weight loss, seizures
BP >180/120 with headache, visual changes, encephalopathy, end-organ damage
differential.tests: BP measurement, fundoscopic exam, renal function, troponin

differential.features: Sudden severe headache, visual field deficits (bitemporal hemianopia), ophthalmoplegia, known or unknown pituitary adenoma
differential.tests: MRI brain with pituitary protocol; hormone levels (cortisol, TSH, prolactin)

differential.features: Orthostatic headache (better lying down, worse upright), may have neck stiffness, subdural fluid collections
differential.tests: MRI brain with contrast (diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement, brain sagging); LP with low opening pressure

differential.features: Recurrent thunderclap headaches, may mimic SAH, associated with vasoactive substances or postpartum
differential.tests: CTA/MRA (segmental vasoconstriction); may require repeat imaging as vasoconstriction evolves

disposition.criteria: Pain controlled to tolerable level (NRS ≤4/10); tolerating oral fluids and medications; no red flag features; able to ambulate; rescue medication and follow-up plan provided; headache diary instructions given

Status migrainosus unresponsive to ED headache cocktail (2 or more treatment rounds); inability to tolerate oral intake despite antiemetics; need for repetitive IV DHE protocol; severe dehydration requiring ongoing IV fluids; concern for secondary headache requiring further workup

Refractory status migrainosus requiring ketamine infusion or sub-anesthetic propofol; hemodynamic instability from treatments (severe hypotension from chlorpromazine); altered mental status not explained by medications; suspected secondary cause requiring ICU-level monitoring

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for services unavailable at current facility (headache specialist, DHE protocol capability, interventional procedures)

Pain controlled on oral medications (NRS ≤3/10 for ≥12 hours); tolerating oral fluids and solid food; ambulatory without significant dizziness; discharge medications reviewed with patient; follow-up with neurology arranged within 2-4 weeks
Post-discharge: 2-4 weeks for treatment assessment; Chronic migraine: q1-3 months; Stable on preventive: q3-6 months
